questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following organisms is most sensitive to penicillin?
questions.explanation:
Among the given organisms, Treponema pallidum is most sensitive to penicillin. Penicillin G 
remains the drug of choice for the treatment of syphilis. Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, and Pneumococcus have developed variable resistance to 
penicillin G and penicillin G is no longer considered the drug of choice for most of the infections 
caused by them.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements about penicillin-binding proteins is false?

options.a: Present within cell membrane of bacteria
options.b: Mutation in the PBPs gives rise to resistance
options.c: PBPs are involved in protein synthesis

questions.explanation:
The targets for the action of -lactam antibiotics are collectively termed penicillin-binding 
proteins (PBPs) and they are not involved in protein synthesis. Transpeptidase enzyme and related proteins constitute the penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) 
which are present in the bacterial cell membrane. Transpepetidase is involved in the synthesis of 
peptidoglycan of the bacterial cell wall. All -lactam groups of antibiotics bind to PBPs and inhibit 
the last step in peptidoglycan synthesis. 494 
Sold by @itachibot Mutation in the different PBPs confers resistance to the bacteria against the beta-lactams. 
Methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) occurs due to alteration in the PBPs. Imipenem targets the PBPs, disrupting cell wall synthesis and causing death of the 
micro-organism. Beta-lactam group of antibiotics include: • Penicillins • Cephalosporins • Carbapenems • Monobactam

questions.question: Question 3: In which of the following patients is penicillin G is not used as treatment?
questions.explanation:
Penicillin G is not used against rickettsial infections like scrub typhus, and tetracyclines are the 
drug of choice in this condition. Penicillins are ineffective against amebae, plasmodia, rickettsiae, fungi or viruses. Uses of penicillin are: • Prophylaxis of rheumatic carditis (benzathine penicillin) • Syphilis • Leptospirosis • Cervicofacial actinomycosis • Rat-bite fever • Meningococcal meningitis • Anthrax • Listeria

questions.question: Question 4: In which of the following conditions is Penicillin G not the drug of choice?
questions.explanation:
Penicillin G is not the drug of choice for Lyme disease, but is an alternative to doxycycline, 
amoxixilline and cefuroxime in the treatment of Lyme disease. Penicillin G is the drug of choice for all forms of actinomycosis, syphilis and rat-bite fever.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is false about penicillins?

options.b: Benzathine penicillin is short acting penicillin
options.c: Cloxacillin is beta lactamase and acid resistant
options.d: Ampicillin is not resistant to beta lactamases

questions.explanation:
Benzathine penicillin G and procaine penicillin G are repository preparations of penicillin G and 
are long-acting. 495 
Sold by @itachibot They are given as deep I.M. injection. Benzathine penicillin has the longest half-life and is 
administered every 2-4 weeks. Penicillin V is an acid-resistant penicillin preparation that is administered orally. Ampicillin has an extended spectrum but is not resistant to beta-lactamases. Penicillinase-resistant penicillins are: • Cloxacillin • Dicloxacillin • Flucloxacillin • Methicillin • Nafcillin

questions.question: Question 6: A patient is prescribed probenecid along with penicillin. What is the rationale behind this?

options.a: It is a beta lactamase inhibitor
options.b: It increases the duration of action of penicillins
options.c: It increases the excretion of penicillins in kidney
options.d: It decreases the metabolism of penicllins in liver

questions.explanation:
Probenecid is used along with penicillin because it increases the duration of action of penicillin. Penicillin is excreted by tubular secretion in the kidney. Probenecid is a uricosuric drug used in 
gout that competes with the same transporter (OATP: organic anion transporter) used by 
penicillin for tubular secretion. Therefore, it decreases the rate of excretion and increases the 
duration of action of penicillin.

questions.question:
Question 7: The culture and sensitivity report from a wound swab is positive for penicillinase-producing 
Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following antimicrobials can be administered?
questions.explanation:
The drug that can be used here is cloxacillin since it is not penicillinase susceptible. 
It is penicillinase-resistant penicillin. Bacteria can inactivate -lactam antibiotics by the action of the -lactamase enzyme. The 
-lactamases enzyme activity can be narrow or broad spectrum. In general, gram-positive bacteria 
produce and secrete a large amount of -lactamase. Most of these enzymes are penicillinases. Penicillinase-resistant penicillins are: • Cloxacillin • Dicloxacillin • Flucloxacillin • Methicillin • Nafcillin Option B: Penicillin G encompasses the natural preparations and salts of penicillin. They have a 
narrow spectrum and are susceptible to penicillinase. Options A and C: Amoxicillin and piperacillin are extended-spectrum penicillins but are 
susceptible to penicillinase. 496 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is not an extended spectrum penicillin?
questions.explanation:
Cloxacillin is not extended-spectrum penicillin. It is penicillinase-resistant penicillin. Extended-spectrum penicillins have greater activity than penicillin against gram-negative bacteria 
because of their enhanced ability to penetrate the Gram-negative outer membrane. Extended-spectrum penicillins are: • Aminopenicillins - ampicillin, amoxicillin • Carboxypenicillins - carbenicillin, ticarcillin • Ureidopenicillins - piperacillin, mezlocillin

questions.question:
Question 9: A 22-year-old woman presented with dysuria and high-grade fever. Urine culture sensitivity 
shows the growth of carbenicillin-sensitive E. coli. Which of the following is true about the 
antibiotic?

options.b: Has no effect in Proteus infection

questions.explanation:
Carbenicillin is effective in Pseudomonas infection. It is extended-spectrum penicillin belonging to the carboxypenicillins group. It has activity against 
Pseudomonas aeruginosa and indole-positive Proteus. It is acid labile and is not administered 
orally. Antipseudomonal penicillins are: • Carboxypenicillins - carbenicillin, ticarcillin • Ureidopenicillins - mezlocillin, piperacillin

questions.question: Question 10: Which among the following is not a beta-lactamase enzyme inhibitor?
questions.explanation:
Piperacillin is not a beta-lactamase enzyme inhibitor. It is an extended-spectrum beta-lactam 
(ureidopenicillin) drug having significant antipseudomonal action. Beta-lactamases are a family of enzymes produced by many gram-positive and gram-negative 
bacteria that inactivate beta-lactam antibiotics by opening the beta-lactam ring. Beta-lactamase inhibitors available for clinical use are: • Clavulanic acid • Sulbactam • Tazobactam • Avibactam

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following antimicrobials is effective against an organism producing 
extended-spectrum beta-lactamases?
questions.explanation:
497 
Sold by @itachibot Piperacillin-tazobactam is an antimicrobial that is effective against organisms producing 
extended-spectrum beta-lactamases. Extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) enzyme produced by bacteria causes resistance to 
most of the penicillins, cephalosporins (third and fourth generation), and monobactams. ESBL is 
most prevalent among gram-negative organisms like Klebsiella and E. coli. ESBL can be inhibited by combining beta-lactamase inhibitors like clavulanic acid or tazobactam. 
Carbapenems and quinolones have inherent activity against ESBL. Note: As piperacillin has greater activity against Klebsiella and other gram-negative organisms 
than amoxicillin, piperacillin-tazobactam can be considered as a better option in this question.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is an acid-susceptible penicillin?
questions.explanation:
Methicillin and nafcillin are penicillinase-resistant penicillins that are acid susceptible and are 
administered parenterally. Methicillin use is associated with higher incidence of interstitial nephritis. Ampicillin, amoxicillin and cloxacillin are acid-resistant penicillins.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient who is being treated with an antimicrobial agent presents with neutropenia. Which 
of the following drugs could be the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Neutropenia is seen with nafcillin. It is penicillinase-resistant parenteral penicillin. It is associated with side effects like neutropenia and interstitial nephritis. In patients with renal 
failure, it is associated with seizures. Methicillin is also a penicillinase-resistant penicillin. Its use is associated with a higher incidence 
of interstitial nephritis than other penicillins, hence it is no longer used.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 28-year-old man undergoing treatment with penicillin presents with fever, myalgia, and 
exacerbation of pre-existing cutaneous lesions. Which of the following diseases is he most 
probably being treated for?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction and it is associated with the use 
of penicillin in syphilis. Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a host immune reaction due to the release of spirochetal antigen 
by the dying T.pallidum in patients on treatment with penicillin. This occurs in primary and most 
cases of secondary syphilis and is characterized by fever, shivering, myalgia, exacerbation of 
lesions and vascular collapse. Symptomatic treatment suffices and penicillin treatment need not 
be interrupted.

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient who is undergoing treatment with antibiotics presents with diarrhea, fever, and 
leukocytosis. Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea is suspected. This condition is most 
commonly associated with the use of which of the following group of drugs?
questions.explanation:
Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea is mostly due to aminopenicillins. 498 
Sold by @itachibot Antibiotic-associated colitis is caused by Clostridium difficile infection due to the destruction of 
the normal gut microbial flora by the use of antibiotics. Although all antibiotics can cause the condition, the most commonly implicated are: • Ampicillin (aminopenicillin) • Clindamycin • Third-generation cephalosporins • Fluoroquinolones.

questions.question:
Question 16: 491 
Sold by @itachibot A patient being treated with ampicillin presents with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. C. 
difficile infection is suspected. Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is approved for 
use in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Bezlotoxumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to Clostridium difficile toxin B, indicated to 
reduce the recurrence of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI). Actoxumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to Clostridium difficile toxin A but it is not 
approved because of lack of efficacy. Adalimumab is an anti-TNF alpha antibody used in rheumatoid arthritis and various other 
conditions.

questions.question: Question 17: Systemic use of bacitracin is restricted due to:
questions.explanation:
The systemic use of bacitracin is restricted due to nephrotoxicity. Bacitracin is a polypeptide antibiotic and it inhibits the synthesis of the bacterial cell wall. Currently, it is used topically for dermal infections and for ophthalmic infections. Parenteral use 
of this antibiotic leads to nephrotoxicity.

questions.question: Question 18: Daptomycin is not indicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Daptomycin is not indicated in community-acquired pneumonia because even though it 
penetrates adequately into the lung, it is inactivated by pulmonary surfactant and thus is not 
useful. Daptomycin is a cyclic lipopeptide antibiotic. It acts by depolarising bacterial membranes 
resulting in loss of membrane potential and cell death. Daptomycin is indicated in the following infections: • Complicated skin and soft-tissue infections • Complicated bacteremia caused by staphylococcus and streptococcus • Right-sided endocarditis • Vancomycin-resistant enterococcal infections 499 
Sold by @itachibot Its efficacy in the above-mentioned conditions is comparable to that of vancomycin.

questions.question: Question 19: Polymyxins are effective against:
questions.explanation:
Polymyxins are effective against gram-negative bacteria. Polymyxin group of antibiotics includes polymyxin B and colistin which have their antimicrobial 
spectrum limited primarily to gram-negative aerobic bacteria. They interact with the phospholipid 
of the bacterial cell membranes and disrupt it. Polymyxins are used in various topical formulations. Parenteral formulations are used only in 
serious systemic infections that are resistant to other antimicrobials. Nephrotoxicity limits 
widespread systemic use.

questions.question:
Question 20: 492 
Sold by @itachibot What is the mechanism of resistance by lactamases■ to -lactam antibiotics?
questions.explanation:
Resistance by lactamases is through the degradation of antibiotics. The bacterial cell wall is made of heteropolymeric peptidoglycan that confers mechanical stability. 
The -lactam antibiotics inhibit the last step in peptidoglycan synthesis by acylating the 
transpeptidase via cleavage of the –CO–N– bond of the -lactam ring. These transpeptidase 
targets are collectively called Penicillin Binding Proteins (PBPs) Beta-lactamases are enzymes produced by certain bacteria that inactivates -lactam antibiotics by 
hydrolysis of the -lactam ring in their structure. The resistance to penicillins and other beta-lactam antibiotics can be conferred through one of the 
four mechanisms: • Inactivation of antibiotic by lactamases • Modification of target PBPs • Impaired penetration of drug to target PBPs • Antibiotic efflux

questions.question:
Question 21: A known asthmatic patient with fever and sore throat was prescribed an antibiotic. Two days 
later he presents with a maculopapular rash. Which of the following drugs might have caused 
this?
questions.explanation:
Skin rashes of all types may be caused by allergy to penicillin. Amoxicillin and ampicillin are aminopenicillins. The incidence of skin rashes appears to be 
highest following the use of ampicillin, at about 9%. Amoxicillin is a close congener of ampicillin with the following features: • Better oral absorption; food does not interfere with the absorption • Incidence of diarrhea is less • More active against penicillin-resistant pneumococci 500 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following statements is correct for a patient on high dose of penicillin and 
gentamicin?

options.a: Greater activity against gram positive bacteria

questions.explanation:
Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that requires therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) as it 
has a narrow therapeutic index. It is nephrotoxic and ototoxic (predominantly vestibular effects). The threshold for toxicity for gentamicin is the plasma concentration of 2 g/mL, the maximum 
recommended for prolonged exposure. Aminoglycoside antibiotics act by binding to the 30s ribosome and inhibiting protein synthesis. 
Their ability to cause misreading of DNA templates and the formation of aberrant proteins that 
get incorporated into bacterial cell membranes makes them bactericidal agents. Common ototoxic drugs are: • Antibiotics - aminoglycosides (gentamicin > tobramycin > amikacin > neomycin), 
erythromycin, tetracyclines. • Chemotherapeutic agents - cisplatin, bleomycin, nitrogen mustards. • High dose aspirin, acetaminophen, NSAID’s • Antimalarials - quinine, quinidine • Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors - sildenafil 501 
Sold by @itachibot Cephalosporins, Vancomycin and Carbapenems
